Football

Trinity captures 6-A region title with win over St. Xavier

Shamrocks play next week in state semifinals

By: Jason Frakes (@kyhighs) November 21, 2014

34 shares
share
tweet
send
email

Sights and sounds of the rematch betweenTrinity and St. Xavier. The Shamrocks won the game and captured he 6-A regional title 9-3.

Its defense healthy and hungry, the Trinity High School football team is back in the state semifinals.

The Shamrocks posted eight quarterback sacks and held rival St. Xavier to minus-15 rushing yards in a 9-3 victory Friday in the Class 6-A, Region One final in front of an estimated 7,000 at Papa John’s Cardinal Stadium.

PHOTOS: Trinity 9, St. X 3

With defensive backs Alex Reisert and Canon Jackson both hobbled by injuries, Trinity allowed 348 total yards and three Noah Houk touchdown passes in a 35-21 loss to St. X during the regular season.

But with Reisert and Jackson healthy and several others contributing, the Trinity defense dominated and capped its effort by forcing four turnovers in the fourth quarter.

RELATED: Semifinal playoff pairings

“We have better chemistry, and everyone has each other’s backs,” junior receiver/defensive back Rodjay Burns said. “We’re just so much better with everybody healthy.”

Burns had two interceptions, Zach Berger had one interception and Jackson recovered a fumble in the fourth quarter. Connor Foos and Brenton Ervin both posted three sacks. Burns and Landon Corolla had a sack apiece.

“They whipped us pretty good from start to finish,” St. X coach Will Wolford said. “We made it exciting at the end, but at no time did I feel comfortable with our offense. They never really found a definite rhythm.”

Trinity (8-5) – No. 1 in The Courier-Journal’s Litkenhous Ratings – won three straight state championships from 2010-12 but was eliminated by Male in last year’s regional final. But now it’s back to the state semifinals and a trip to Meade County (10-2) next week.

Meade County, last year’s state runner-up to Scott County, beat previously unbeaten Central Hardin 30-8 in Friday’s Region Two final.

“We’re hungry,” Foos said. “We can’t wait for this next game. We’re ready.”

Along with his stellar defensive play, Burns set up the Trinity offense with a big special-teams play in the second quarter. Burns fielded a punt at his 20-yard line, broke left and raced 53 yards before being brought down at the St. X 27.

“If I catch it I know my team is going to have my back,” Burns said. “I just took it and ran with it. I thought it was a touchdown, but I kind of fumbled it and got caught.”

Six plays later Andrew Deye kicked a 21-yard field goal to give the Shamrocks a 3-0 lead with 5:52 left in the first half.

Trinity went to its running game to score the game’s only touchdown in the fourth quarter. After a short punt gave the Shamrocks the ball at the St. X 44-yard line, they needed just five plays to score on a 14-yard run by Jailen Reed at the 9:55 mark.

Donald Brooks carried three times for 25 yards on the drive, and Reed had two carries for 19 yards.

“The offensive line on that drive did an outstanding job,” Trinity coach Bob Beatty said.

Houk went out with a knee injury late in the fourth quarter and gave way to sophomore quarterback Desmond Ridder. He led the Tigers on a scoring drive that was capped by Michael Bennett’s 32-yard field goal, making it 9-3 with 1:04 left.

St. Xavier then tried an onside kick, but Brooks recovered it and Trinity ran out the clock.

Brooks (18 carries, 53 yards) and Reed (12 carries, 42 yards) led Trinity’s ground attack. Ryan Young completed 14 of 19 passes for 127 yards but was intercepted twice.

TaiJon Smith, the top rusher this season for No. 3 St. X (8-5), was limited to zero yards on four carries while battling a muscle strain. Houk completed 12 of 24 passes for 169 yards with one interception.

For Beatty, it marked his 13th regional title in 15 seasons as Trinity’s head coach. 

“Obviously you’d like more points on offense,” he said, “but when you have rivalry games like this you want one more point than them and you move on.”

Jason Frakes can be reached at (502) 582-4046 and followed on Twitter @kyhighs. 

Trinity 0 3 0 6 - 9
St. Xavier 0 0 0 3 - 3

T – Andrew Deye 21 FG; T – Jailen Reed 14 run (kick blocked); SX – Michael Bennett 32 FG.

T X
Total yards 227 236
First downs 11 12
Rushes-yds. 37-100 27-(-15)
Comp-Att-Int 14-19-2 15-32-3
Passing yards 127 251
Fumbles-lost 1-0 2-1
Penalties-yds. 7-26.1 6-33
Punts-avg. 2-12 3-25

Trinity, Louisville, St. Xavier High School (multiple), Trinity high school for boys, Football
